HAL is 'lean' because it tackles only a small set of capabilities.
It's con=
trols are essentially limited to outbound links and embedded
content.

Ther=
e are no forms in HAL and this was a deliberate design decision
based on th=
e assertion that such mechanisms rely on a level of
sophistication that is =
just not realistic at the moment. Basically,
adding forms wouldn't achieve =
much and would increase the costs of
adopting it as a format. I am working =
on a separate design which
extends HAL to add in templated writes or 'forms=
', but this will be a
separate type and not a new version of HAL.

On Tue, =
Jan 3, 2012 at 3:52 PM, mike amundsen <mamund@...> wrote:

>
>=
 your responses surprise me (only a bit<g>) since you are the one
> person =
on this list who has designed, and actively promotes, a
> hyper-media type =
which you describe as: =A0"...machine-readable and
> designed to be consume=
d by automated 'agents'."[1]

html

 fair. =A0There is a single shared semantic

s, and our brains (so far) are way better

ared to software code.
>>> </snip>
>>>
>>> think about what you say here: t=
hat there is a "shared semantic"
>>> understanding. and where does this und=
erstanding exist? only (and
>>> solely) in the head of humans?
>>>
>>> afte=
r careful review, i claim you will find that there *are*
>>> real-world mar=
kers, indicators, semantic "switches" that exist in the
>>> real world; one=
s that are recognized, parsed, and (when appropriate)
>>> activated by huma=
ns. Currently, thesemarkers are the visual cues that
>>> are rendered by co=
mmon Web browsers via the messages sent by servers
>>> in the most ubiquito=
us human-centered hypermedia format of the day;
>>> HTML.
>>>
>>> "Semantic=
 meaning" is an emergent property. In the case of HTML that
>>> property is=
 "created" by humans when they observe the visual
>>> "landscape" rendered =
by =A0Web browsers.
>>>
>>> Does anyone here want to assert that this "sema=
ntic meaning" can
>>> _only_ emerge when humans are *directly* involved in =
the real-time
>>> interpretation of messages that contain these (or similar=
) markers?
>>
>> Afaict, there's a spectrum of sophistication here. I haven=
't seen a
>> client implementation which demonstrates automated capabilitie=
s which
>> come 'close' to that of a human, we're basically talking about t=
he
>> web's version of a Turing Test.
>>
>> Most of the evidence so far sug=
gests this is the case, although I am
>> not an AI expert.
>>
>>> Or
>>> is=
 it possible that humans can "code" agents to have (at least some
>>> of) t=
his same ability to recognize, parse, and activate the
>>> "affordances" fo=
und in the hypermedia landscape?
>>>
>>> It is my assertion that the latter=
 is the case. I also contend that
>>> making the assumption that this is po=
ssible is a key step in advancing
>>> the art and theory of distributed hyp=
ermedia.
>>>
>>
>> I think it's an interesting research topic but the compl=
exity of
>> producing these sorts of clients is so high, it's inevitable th=
at only
>> a small portion of your client base will behave this way (unless=
 you
>> control them all, in which case your system is not very distributed=
!).
>> So, in practice, you will be forced to only evolve your application =
in
>> a way that caters to the lowest common denominator - undermining the
=
>> effort that has gone into more sophisticated clients. This is a big
>> c=
hallenge to overcome in and of itself, irrespective of the challenge
>> of =
inventing the designs for such an autonomous hypermedia agent.
